0.04.text:
Next is a lead researcher of policies for
design and innovation at Design Wales-

5.96.text:
-part of the National Centre for Product
Design and Development Research.

12.08.text:
Since 2009, she has been coordinating
the SEE network of 11 European partners-

19.00.text:
-sharing international best practice
to accelerate the integration of design-

27.24.text:
Since 2013, she has also been
a board member at BEDA-

32.84.text:
-Bureau of European Design Associations
with SVID's CEO, Robin Edman.

38.20.text: She has worked at the UK parliament-

41.48.text:
-as a press officer in the French
Ministry of European Affairs-

45.72.text:
-and as assistant marketing manager
for Siemens in Paris.

50.56.text:
In parallel to her work,
she is undertaking a PhD-

54.00.text:
-to analyse design
as a driver of innovation policy.

57.72.text:
Please welcome Anna Whicher -
give her a hand!

68.88.text:
And thank you to the Swedish Industrial
Design Foundation for inviting me today.

75.12.text:
Now, as Eva-Karin already said,
sitting is the new smoking.

80.68.text: So I'd like you to all stand up, please.

88.52.text:
As you know, the title of the conference
today is Mission: User.

93.32.text:
You are my users, so I'd like
to understand a little bit more about you.

98.80.text:
I'd like to know what type of people
we have in the audience.

104.64.text:
If you're not a designer,
please, can you sit down?

113.96.text:
OK, that's great. Thank you.
If you'd all like to stand up again, please.

119.60.text:
OK, if you don't work
in the public sector or in government-

126.48.text:
-please sit down. Civil servants and
government officials remain. Fantastic!

133.12.text:
That's a really good split between
designer audience and public officials.

138.44.text: Can you all please stand up again?

141.12.text:
Now I need to find out
who hasn't remained standing.

145.84.text:
If you are an academic,
can you remain standing?

149.92.text:
If you're not an academic,
can you please sit down?

153.68.text:
OK, a few sneaky academics
coming in there. Thank you very much.

158.84.text:
If you'd all like to sit down,
that's great. Lovely.

169.16.text:
OK, based on what Laura already said
about making policy sexy for designers-

176.20.text:
-I want to now make design sexy
for those of you based in government.

185.68.text:
As Helena said, I'm based in PDR
in Cardiff in Wales.

191.12.text:
I've learnt today it's the same size
as Jokkmokk, which is brilliant.

195.96.text:
A trivia question I hope might come up
in a pub quiz at some stage.

202.32.text: To start at the beginning: design.

206.08.text:
This is not a question
I want to spend long on-

210.20.text:
-but from today's discussion
it is clear-

213.32.text:
-that design is a difficult concept
for policymakers to grasp.

218.64.text:
Because you can't predict what the outcome
of the process is going to be.

225.00.text:
Imagine if you're a government official
and you want to potentially use-

232.64.text:
But the person you're contracting
can't necessarily tell you-

237.00.text:
-what the outcome is going to be
at the start. That's a problem!

242.24.text:
It is a real challenge for designers
to try to communicate-

246.32.text:
-why that is a good approach
for governments.

249.44.text:
Why co-creating the solution
with users is a good approach.

254.36.text:
When I talk about design
with government-

257.56.text:
-I talk about design being an approach
to problem solving-

261.64.text:
-that starts with, as we've said,
an understanding of user needs.

267.16.text:
Therefore, as a process
that starts from user needs-

271.16.text:
-it can be applied to products,
services, processes-

282.16.text:
-the definitions of both design
and policymaking are so crucial.

287.96.text:
Making decisions
that are better for society-

291.84.text:
-that's crucially
what both of them are about.

296.24.text:
And because of
these new trends in government-

300.08.text:
-the trend of developing policies
in closer collaboration with citizens-

305.64.text:
-design is gaining attention across Europe
at multiple levels of governance.

311.16.text:
At the European Commission,
in national and regional governments-

315.84.text:
-and even local governments,
as we heard from La 27e Région.

321.36.text:
The EC has developed
an action plan for design.

325.52.text:
They state that design as a tool for
user-centred and market-driven innovation-

332.28.text:
-in all sectors of the economy,
complementary to R&D-

340.00.text:
So this is about not only using design
to drive innovation-

347.16.text:
-but using design
across different policy domains.

350.92.text:
Design for health policy,
environment policy, transport policy-

356.24.text:
-for regional development and rurality,
as we've already heard.

362.12.text:
I would like to give you a brief overview
of the project that I run-

367.00.text:
-and some lessons we've learnt for how
to communicate design to policymakers.

373.68.text:
And how design can have a real impact
in the policymaking process.

378.52.text:
SEE stands for
Sharing Experience Europe.

382.16.text:
It's a network of 11 design centres
across Europe, using design methods-

388.96.text:
-to develop innovation policy
and innovation programmes.

394.20.text:
As Robin already said,
one of the best ways-

397.96.text:
-to get design integrated into policy
is integrating innovation policy.

403.00.text:
Do we need a separate design policy?
Maybe.

407.76.text:
By having design integrated
into innovation policy-

411.36.text:
-you have a broad understanding;
design included across policy domains.

416.72.text:
But a dedicated design action plan
also gives depth:

420.48.text:
The specific design related actions,
such as in business support programmes-

426.52.text:
-or in specific education initiatives,
such as apprenticeships.

430.92.text:
So I think we need both
design included in innovation policy-

435.20.text:
-as well as
dedicated design action plans.

438.40.text:
Countries like Denmark, Latvia,
France, Estonia, and Finland-

450.80.text:
I'd like to just give you a few lessons
of what we've learnt.

454.92.text:
As I said, design is a very difficult
concept for policymakers to grasp.

460.36.text:
Instead of telling them, we've tried
to show them what design is.

464.88.text:
We've involved over 800 policymakers
in 100 hands-on workshops-

471.24.text:
-that use design tools,
such as stakeholder mapping-

476.00.text:
-ideation, customer journey mapping,
and service blueprinting.

480.44.text:
Methods I'm sure many of you
are familiar with.

483.72.text:
By actually involving them
in these hands-on workshops-

488.64.text:
-you see the light-bulb go on,
they understand the value of design.

493.52.text:
This has been a much better way
to communicate design.

498.00.text:
What we've therefore done is develop
design policy using design methods-

510.24.text:
It's also important to create a network
of policymakers who use design methods.

516.16.text:
It's not enough
to do a one-off design project-

519.24.text:
-and hope that people in government
continue to use design.

523.32.text:
We have to embed these lessons by
training civil servants in design methods.

529.88.text:
As I said,
we've engaged over 800 policymakers-

534.04.text:
-training them
in half-day workshops in design.

538.64.text:
Data is a big thing in design. The first
thing that policymakers want to know is:

544.64.text:
What is the return investment
if I invest in a design project?

548.64.text:
There's still a lot of work to be done
and I encourage all previous speakers-

554.00.text:
-to evaluate your projects,
your case studies-

557.40.text:
-so that you can communicate
those results-

561.08.text:
-to other policymakers
and create a snowball effect.

565.24.text:
So we've looked at how companies
in Europe use design.

570.12.text:
I'm sure you're familiar with
the Danish design ladder-

574.16.text:
-which diagnoses companies
according to four stages:

578.80.text:
No Design, Design as Styling,
Design as Process-

584.20.text:
-and at the top, Design as Strategy -
as a driver of the business model.

590.24.text:
In Sweden,
this research was done in 2004.

594.80.text:
The value of benchmarking design
is about doing it regularly.

599.72.text:
The Commission, right now,
is doing a study-

602.76.text:
-on how companies across the 28
European member states use design.

607.68.text:
This is going to be the first time
we've ever had this Pan-European data.

612.56.text:
I'd love to persuade the Commission
to do the same from the public sector.

617.64.text:
How strategically are different parts
of the public sector using design?

623.00.text:
We looked also at public and private
spending on design.

628.16.text:
I think the UK
is quite unique in Europe-

631.24.text:
-as we are possibly the only country
in Europe where the private sector-

638.52.text:
-spends more on design
than they do on traditional R&D.

644.00.text:
Another crucial thing
is telling a story.

647.72.text:
We've talked about how design
is fantastic at capturing user empathy.

652.56.text:
Let's use that
when we tell stories to government.

656.04.text:
We've developed a case study booklet,
"Design for Public Good"-

660.48.text:
-which has a series of case studies
of design in the public sector.

665.72.text:
Design never operates alone; it's connected
to every part of the innovation system.

672.40.text:
Design is not going to solve
all the problems for government-

678.68.text:
-but it can really contribute.
Yet there are certain weaknesses-

683.24.text:
-that we need to be aware of.
We've talked about service designers.

687.84.text:
A number of service designers stood up,
which is fantastic.

692.40.text:
We need to be realistic.
There's a skills gap in the design sector-

696.88.text:
-certainly in the UK,
and potentially all across Europe.

700.80.text:
Professional designers are not engaging
in continuous professional development.

707.32.text:
New developments in the discipline,
such as design for policymaking-

712.28.text:
-are still potentially slightly beyond
the mainstream of a majority of designers.

719.88.text:
Promotion is a big thing as well.
How do we tap into new audiences?

724.60.text:
I was pleased when Robin said that
there were plenty of new faces here.

731.20.text:
It's about tapping into new audiences,
talking to health care professionals-

736.60.text:
-talking to local policymakers, and people
in charge of business support programmes.

743.96.text:
The issue of professional skills
among designers-

747.44.text:
-is closely connected to education
and research in design.

751.68.text:
Are the design schools
at the cutting edge-

755.48.text:
-or are they still teaching the same
curriculums as the last decade or two?

761.52.text:
So to contribute to policymaking,
integrating design into innovation policy-

768.04.text:
-we've been looking at mapping
design innovation systems.

772.44.text:
These are the actors and initiatives
in place in a country.

777.36.text:
We looked, obviously, at Wales,
looking at what initiatives there are-

783.56.text:
-for those nine components
of the design innovation ecosystem.

789.12.text:
By understanding who the players are
you can create networks of collaboration-

795.04.text:
-and identify what the gaps are,
so you can build on them-

802.28.text:
So it's about jointly developing policy
with all the actors on the ground.

809.72.text:
This idea of ecosystem mapping
isn't just for design innovation.

814.16.text:
It can be done for a whole range
of policy domains:

818.00.text:
For environment, circular economy,
health care, welfare.

825.44.text:
It's about using the techniques to develop
more holistic, user-focused policies-

835.20.text:
A couple of examples of the actions
included in the policy-

840.60.text:
-we have developed
with the Welsh government.

843.84.text:
We developed it in collaboration
with the policy beneficiaries:

848.60.text:
Academics, industry, designers,
third sector organisations in Wales.

855.04.text:
We looked at training of innovation
specialists in the Welsh government.

860.36.text:
They provide business support.
They're experts in tax, in law-

866.36.text:
-in establishing change management
and business processes.

870.96.text:
They know a little bit about design,
but it isn't their domain.

875.36.text:
By providing
additional training in design-

878.76.text:
-they can communicate those
to the SMEs they work with.

883.28.text:
Being biased, Wales is one of the best
places in the UK to start a company.

889.84.text:
You have so much government support:
Subsidies to buy equipment-

894.76.text:
-free training, mentoring, tax credits,
grants - there's an infinite list.

901.00.text:
But an infinite list can be complicated
for SMEs to navigate.

907.04.text:
Many SMEs didn't know where to access
the most appropriate support for them.

913.72.text:
So we did a mapping of all
the different innovation programmes-

920.48.text:
-available through the Welsh government
to see if it was possible-

925.00.text:
-to make the process more streamlined
and clear for businesses.

933.64.text:
The business support structure
has been much more consolidated.

938.60.text:
So now, multiple competences,
including design-

946.64.text:
The landscape is so much easier
for SMEs to navigate.

952.56.text:
As Robin said, it's about integrating
design into all innovation programmes-

958.80.text:
-so that every SME who interfaces
with government support-

963.00.text:
-has the opportunity to access
some form of design support.

966.92.text:
As I said previously, more continuous
professional opportunities for designers.

973.28.text:
I think design apprenticeships
will become really big in Europe.

979.60.text:
Higher education in design isn't necessarily
performing the function it should be.

986.28.text:
Professional design agencies
are having to retrain graduates.

991.88.text:
So we are trying to introduce
a work-based learning diploma.

997.16.text:
The students actually work
within a design agency-

1002.00.text:
-to get the business experience
they need.

1005.44.text:
Of course, we're looking to access
education opportunities at every level-

1016.08.text:
We already heard Christian mention
how an increasing number of designers-

1021.72.text:
-are being placed within
public authorities at multiple levels.

1026.08.text:
We also set up
a design and development grant-

1029.08.text:
-specifically aimed at startups
and young entrepreneurs.

1033.52.text:
So capture impact -
what has SEE achieved?

1036.72.text:
We've influenced 17 policies
and 40 programmes for innovation.

1042.72.text:
They include the Welsh government
innovation strategy-

1047.32.text:
-the strategy for South Bohemia,
Central Finland, Silesia, and Flanders.

1054.08.text:
Plus a number of innovation programmes,
such as tax credits and grants.

1060.56.text:
Just to finish,
I'd like to make a few predictions-

1069.08.text:
I hope that by saying them,
they will come true.

1076.48.text:
I think that increasingly, we'll see design
as an approach to policymaking.

1083.28.text:
Not just innovation policymaking,
the focus om my programme-

1087.60.text:
-but across
a broad range of disciplines.

1091.16.text:
I think we'll see a number of dedicated
design action plans across Europe.

1097.60.text:
I think we'll also see civil servants
being trained more in design methods-

1104.00.text:
-and more design managers at multiple
levels of governance across Europe.

1109.48.text:
I think that we'll see more innovation
programmes with a specific component-

1115.36.text:
-for design, as well as more
dedicated design programmes.

1122.16.text:
If this is a topic that is of interest
to you, please catch me afterwards.

1127.76.text: I have some questions for you as well.

1132.40.text: Thank you so much, Anna Whicher!

1141.64.text:
While we are waiting on the questions,
I'll give you this chocolate.

1147.68.text:
-Oh, thank you! Tack!
-Continue asking Anna questions.

1152.96.text:
We only have one at the moment,
at the Mentimeter, govote.at.

1158.80.text:
I think you know the code already,
so continue to ask questions.

1164.40.text:
And Anna also has two questions
for you.

1169.08.text:
My question for you is,
does Sweden need-

1173.16.text:
-a design policy
or a design action plan?

1182.40.text: I think the answer is pretty clear.

1186.00.text:
If you think differently,
you have to hurry up and answer.

1205.08.text:
We're having elections in the UK
next month.

1209.12.text:
We expect that the voting turnout
will be about 36 %.

1213.48.text:
So this is representative of turnout
in UK elections.

1229.20.text:
Nobody feels passionately against a design
policy; I'll take that as a good thing.

1236.04.text:
And then my next question for you is,
to embed design for policymaking-

1243.20.text:
-should we be training the top 100
civil servants in design thinking?

1259.96.text:
-And Anna, what do you think?
-Absolutely, in case you hadn't guessed.

1266.20.text:
Maybe you can explain why to
the people answering "I don't know".

1271.08.text:
I think... We already had
several questions this morning-

1275.04.text:
-about implementation
and about making ideas stick.

1279.44.text:
In order to foster this idea
that design really is a method-

1289.12.text:
-we need to introduce design methods
at every level of governance.

1293.60.text:
But as we said, you need to have
the buy-in from the top level-

1299.00.text:
-the senior civil servants, in order to
mobilise decision-making in government.

1305.80.text:
Great.
I think the answer is pretty clear.

1311.28.text:
Let's switch to
the audience questions for Anna.

1319.40.text:
OK, we have two.
Can you read them yourself?

1324.76.text:
Which user needs in society
isn't design able to address?

1330.04.text:
It's a good question.
I think to a certain extent-

1334.32.text:
-design can be applied to any process,
but I think it does have limits.

1341.08.text:
Because, inevitably, design is about
synthesising a large range of input.

1347.80.text:
So with these super-wicked problems
that Christian was talking about-

1353.24.text:
-how do you involve thousands of
stakeholders in a hands-on design process?

1360.92.text:
I think we need to move beyond
traditional consultation methods-

1366.80.text:
-and try to mobilise large sections
of the population to use design.

1373.08.text:
But that's the challenge. Anyone
who's involved more than 2 000 users-

1379.92.text:
-in a hands-on process,
I'd be very keen to hear about that.

1385.08.text:
Wait with the middle one and end
with that one. That's a good one.

1391.68.text:
What's my elevator pitch to sell design
as a process to non-design believers?

1398.88.text:
-Do you want to do that one last?
-Yeah, I can.

1402.92.text:
-Gives me a chance to think about it...
-How should civil servants be educated?

1409.08.text:
Like I said, it's difficult
to tell people what design is-

1413.04.text:
-you really do need to show them.
If you introduce simple design tools-

1418.72.text:
-you can create an appetite
for that way of working.

1423.24.text:
You can then introduce more complex
design methods to civil servants.

1430.56.text:
I can't... I don't know what language
that is. Swedish, something?

1435.08.text:
How can Swedish be involved in...
I don't understand that question.

1443.00.text:
Oh, I think it's... Once again.
How can inhabitants...?

1453.20.text:
...in Sweden be able to...
Actors - that's a good one!

1458.88.text: So it should put into that sentence?

1461.64.text:
How can Swedish actors
be involved in SEE?

1465.24.text:
Great! I am trying to persuade
Robin to be more involved.

1469.36.text:
I'd love to come to facilitate
a design policy process-

1476.64.text:
But I think there's lots of lessons
that Swedish actors can take-

1482.00.text:
-from the SEE platform already,
and I hope-

1486.32.text:
-that we can continue this conversation,
certainly through BEDA-

1491.84.text:
-and also through Design for Europe,
a follow-on initiative...

1497.60.text:
-...by the European Commission.
-I think you're right.

1501.48.text:
Robin will actually be the president
of BEDA in June, so that's a good start.

1507.20.text:
OK, is it easy to develop
a design innovation ecosystem-

1512.08.text:
-for instance for Stockholm?
How much effort is needed?

1516.20.text:
Stockholm already has
a design innovation ecosystem-

1521.48.text:
-but I think there'd be value
in mapping what it looks like.

1526.12.text:
And potentially fostering greater
collaboration between certain actors-

1530.68.text:
-which may not be collaborating
to the extent they should be.

1535.20.text:
So as I said, bridging the gaps
and capitalising on the strengths.

1541.12.text:
And how can you make sure
that controversial ideas-

1545.36.text:
-that might be the result of a design
process actually get implemented?

1550.16.text:
Good! Very often you have a workshop
with civil servants and designers-

1556.24.text:
-and at the end of the day everyone's
really excited, energetic, it was great.

1562.44.text:
Back at the office you get bogged down
in your daily work again.

1567.32.text:
I think it's important to capitalise
on those ideas quickly.

1571.60.text:
So it's about creating a panel
of experts-

1576.48.text:
-whether that's in the department
or across different government depts.-

1583.76.text:
-to make sure that those ideas
are not just visions-

1592.96.text:
OK, great. And now the last one -
the elevator pitch.

1597.44.text:
OK, my elevator pitch
to non-design believers.

1602.20.text:
I think public governance is changing,
people are getting frustrated-

1606.96.text:
-with the way governments operate,
and even politicians-

1612.08.text:
-and public administrators recognise
that we need new processes.

1617.88.text:
Design is a process that can capture
the hearts and minds of the citizens.

1624.68.text:
The process is a two-way relationship
between government and citizens-

1632.32.text:
-where both can jointly develop solutions
for the better of society.

1637.56.text:
Wow, good one!
Thank you very much, Anna Whicher.
